revised_title: Internal Stress and Plastic Flow in Mild Steel: Stress-Strain Curves for Atomic Lattice of Higher Carbon Steels
tldr: The authors conducted experiments on mild steel to study the internal stress created by plastic flow and the stress-strain curves for the atomic lattice of higher carbon steels. They discovered that when the external yield stress is exceeded, a new type of secondary internal stress is produced by the process of plastic flow. This stress is permanent and can be measured by the residual lattice strains exhibited by the lattice after the removal of the external stress. The authors also found that the maximum residual internal strain developed by the lattice increases with the fineness to which the crystals can be broken down by plastic deformation.
